Le Triomphe de 1810 (The Triumph of 1810), also referred to as Triomphe de Napoléon (Napoléon's Triumph), adorns the lower section of the southeast pillar of the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1427731797">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a>, facing <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1428522133">Avenue de Champs-Élysées<a>. The sculptured high relief, executed by Jean-Pierre Cortot depicts Napoléon, crowned by Victory, in antique vestments pressing a sword against his chest. In the background, oto the right, a profiled kneeling man symbolizes a prisoner enchained at the feet of the victor. To the left, an allegory of a city, with a crenelated crown, kneels before the conqueror whose protective hands extends over her. Behind the Muse of History inscribes on a tablet the memorable events of Napoléon's reign. Above, sounding a trumpet and bearing a standard, winged Fame soars across a palm tree, an image evoking the Egyptian expedition. The scene illustrates the year 1810, the date of the apogee of Napoléon's reign, his marriage to Marie-Louise of Austria to assure the future of the dynasty, and conquests which expanded the Empire to the maximum. Cortot's Fame serves as pendant to <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1427737925">Rude's Genius of Liberty<a>. The Arc de Triomphe stands in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle, also known as the Place de l'Étoile (Star Square). Designed by Jean Chalgrin between 1806 and 1836, the 51 meter high, 45-meter wide monument is the second largest triumphal arch in existence. It honors those who fought for France, particularly during the Napoleonic Wars.

The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a><strong> is one of the most famous monuments in <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiParis" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Paris<a><strong>. It stands in the centre of the <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPlace_de_l'Étoile" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Place Charles de Gaulle<a><strong> (originally named <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiPlace_de_l'Étoile" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Place de l'Étoile<a><strong>), at the western end of the <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiChamps-Élysées" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Avenue des Champs-Élysées<a><strong>. The <strong><a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">Arc de Triomphe<a><strong> ("Triumphal Arch") honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and the Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I. See <a href"#en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" target"_blank" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a>
Across the street from the Arc de Triomphe with the Eiffel Tower in the background (to get to the Arc, you have go underground because it's impossible to cross the street circling the Arc).

L'arc de Triomphe de Bucarest a été construit en 1935 pour commémorer la réunification de la Roumanie en 1918. Haut de 30 m (17 m d'ouverture), il s'inspire de son homologue parisien.

The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel was designed much like the triumphal arches you may have seen from the Roman Empire, with one large arch and surrounded by two smaller ones each side. You may also like <a href"http:www.eutouring.com" rel"nofollow">www.eutouring.com<a>

The Arc de Triomphe, in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle, also known as the Place de l'Étoile (Star Square), at the western end of <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1429400056">Avenue de Champs-Élysées<a>, honors those who fought for France, particularly during the Napoleonic Wars. The linchpin of L'Axe historique, the monument stands 49.5 meters high, 45 meters wide, and 22 meters deep. The arch was commissioned in 1906, after the victory of Austerlitz, by Emperor Napoleon. It took nearly two years to lay the foundations. Architect and designer Jean Chagrin died just 5 years into the project, and was replaced by Huyon. Construction halted during the restoration and would not be completed until the reign of King Louis-Philippe, in 1833–36 when the architects on site were Goust, then Huyot, under the direction of Héricart de Thury. Each of the four pillars of the arch are adorned, on the lower section, with a sculptural group--Jean-Pierre Cortot's <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1428450809"><i>Le Triumph de 1810<i><a> on the southeast pillar; Antoine Etex' <i><a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1429327146">La Résistance de 1814<i><a> on the southwest pillar; Antoine Etex' <i><a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1427820633">La Paix<a><i> on the northwest pillar; and François Rude's <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1428618504"><i>La Marsellaise<i><a> on the northeast pillar. <i><i>

The Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile is one of the most famous monuments in Paris. It stands in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle (originally named Place de l'Étoile), at the western end of the Champs-Élysées. The Arc de Triomphe (Triumphal Arch) honours those who fought and died for France in the French Revolutionary and the Napoleonic Wars, with the names of all French victories and generals inscribed on its inner and outer surfaces. Beneath its vault lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier from World War I. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.org<a>

Der Arc de Triomphe wurde von Napoleon nach der Schlacht von Austerlitz zur Verherrlichung seiner Siege 1806 in Auftrag gegeben. Am 15. August 1806 wurde der Grundstein zum Bau gelegt. Die Bauarbeiten zogen sich jedoch bis 1836 hin. Der Triumphbogen ist 49,54 m hoch, 44,82 m breit und 22 m tief. Der große Gewölbebogen misst 29,19 m in der Höhe und 14,62 m in der Breite, der kleine Bogen 18,68 m in der Höhe und 8,44 m in der Breite. Der Entwurf ist im Stil der antiken römischen Architektur gehalten. Die vier Figurengruppen an der Basis des Bogens zeigen Der Triumph von 1810, Widerstand, Frieden und La Marseillaise oder Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792 (von François Rude). Oben sind auf den Flächen rund um den Bogen Flachreliefs mit Nachbildungen von wichtigen revolutionären und napoleonischen Siegen eingelassen.Berühmt ist dieser Triumphbogen auch wegen der bedeutenden Reliefs, die er trägt. Sie wurden 1833 in Auftrag gegeben bei den Bildhauern Antoine Étex, Jean-Pierre Cortot und vor allem François Rude. Die Ostfassade zeigt das berühmteste Relief, die „Marseillaise“ (Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792) von François Rude (1784–1855), die auch „Le chant du départ“, also das Abschiedslied, genannt wird. Es handelt sich um eine Gruppe ausziehender Krieger – offensichtlich in revolutionärer oder erhoben nationaler Gesinnung, die – zumindest kann man das in dieser Szene vermuten – das neue Revolutionslied der „Marseillaise“ auf den Lippen haben, das erst am 25. April 1792 komponiert worden war. Interessant ist ein Vergleich der beiden Reliefs dieser Seite. Es handelt sich auf der anderen Seite um den „Triumph Napoleons nach dem Frieden von 1810“ (der „Triumph“ verherrlicht den Frieden von Wien) von Cortot. Das Relief von Cortot steht noch ganz in der Tradition der klassizistischen Statik, der gemessenen Heldenverehrung, des symmetrischen, wohlproportionierten Bildaufbaus – mit anderen Worten der „erhabenen Langeweile“. Auch bei den Reliefs von Antoine Etex auf der Westseite ist diese Atmosphäre deutlich zu spüren, beispielsweise beim „Frieden“. Hier hat man noch den Eindruck, dass die Themen von einer Schauspielertruppe auf einer Theaterbühne dargestellt werden, dass hier Motive aus dem Arsenal zusammengestellt worden sind. Auf den vier Außenseiten des Bodens befinden sich sechs Flachreliefs, die jeweils berühmte Schlachten zeigen. Unter den sechs Bildhauern ist auch Jean-Jacques Feuchère mit einer Darstellung des Übergangs über die Brücke von Arcole zu sehen. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29<a> The astylar design is by Jean Chalgrin (1739–1811), in the Neoclassical version of ancient Roman architecture (see, for example, the triumphal Arch of Titus). Major academic sculptors of France are represented in the sculpture of the Arc de Triomphe: Jean-Pierre Cortot; François Rude; Antoine Étex; James Pradier and Philippe Joseph Henri Lemaire. The main sculptures are not integral friezes but are treated as independent trophies applied to the vast ashlar masonry masses, not unlike the gilt-bronze appliqués on Empire furniture. The four sculptural groups at the base of the Arc are The Triumph of 1810 (Cortot), Resistance and Peace (both by Antoine Étex) and the most renowned of them all, Departure of the Volunteers of 1792 commonly called La Marseillaise (François Rude). The face of the allegorical representation of France calling forth her people on this last was used as the belt buckle for the honorary rank of Marshal of France. Since the fall of Napoleon (1815), the sculpture representing Peace is interpreted as commemorating the Peace of 1815. In the attic above the richly sculptured frieze of soldiers are 30 shields engraved with the names of major Revolutionary and Napoleonic military victories. The inside walls of the monument list the names of 660 people, among which are 558 French generals of the First French Empire; the names of those who died in battle are underlined. Also inscribed, on the shorter sides of the four supporting columns, are the names of the major victorious battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The battles that took place in the period between the departure of Napoleon from Elba to his final defeat at Waterloo are not included. There was at the top of the Arc from 1882 to 1886, a monumental sculpture by Alexandre Falguière, "Le triomphe de la Révolution" (the Triumph of the Revolution), a chariot drawn by horses preparing "to crush Anarchy and Despotism", that remained only four years up there before falling in ruins. Inside the monument, a new permanent exhibition conceived by the artist Maurice Benayoun and the architect Christophe Girault opened in February 2007. The steel and new media installation interrogates the symbolism of the national monument, questioning the balance of its symbolic message during the last two centuries, oscillating between war and peace. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe<a>

Die Ostfassade zeigt das berühmteste Relief, die „Marseillaise“ (Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792) von François Rude (1784–1855), die auch „Le chant du départ“, also das Abschiedslied, genannt wird. Es handelt sich um eine Gruppe ausziehender Krieger – offensichtlich in revolutionärer oder erhoben nationaler Gesinnung, die – zumindest kann man das in dieser Szene vermuten – das neue Revolutionslied der „Marseillaise“ auf den Lippen haben, das erst am 25. April 1792 komponiert worden war. Interessant ist ein Vergleich der beiden Reliefs dieser Seite. Es handelt sich auf der anderen Seite um den „Triumph Napoleons nach dem Frieden von 1810“ (der „Triumph“ verherrlicht den Frieden von Wien) von Cortot. Das Relief von Cortot steht noch ganz in der Tradition der klassizistischen Statik, der gemessenen Heldenverehrung, des symmetrischen, wohlproportionierten Bildaufbaus – mit anderen Worten der „erhabenen Langeweile“. Auch bei den Reliefs von Antoine Etex auf der Westseite ist diese Atmosphäre deutlich zu spüren, beispielsweise beim „Frieden“. Hier hat man noch den Eindruck, dass die Themen von einer Schauspielertruppe auf einer Theaterbühne dargestellt werden, dass hier Motive aus dem Arsenal zusammengestellt worden sind. Auf den vier Außenseiten des Bodens befinden sich sechs Flachreliefs, die jeweils berühmte Schlachten zeigen. Unter den sechs Bildhauern ist auch Jean-Jacques Feuchère mit einer Darstellung des Übergangs über die Brücke von Arcole zu sehen. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29<a> The astylar design is by Jean Chalgrin (1739–1811), in the Neoclassical version of ancient Roman architecture (see, for example, the triumphal Arch of Titus). Major academic sculptors of France are represented in the sculpture of the Arc de Triomphe: Jean-Pierre Cortot; François Rude; Antoine Étex; James Pradier and Philippe Joseph Henri Lemaire. The main sculptures are not integral friezes but are treated as independent trophies applied to the vast ashlar masonry masses, not unlike the gilt-bronze appliqués on Empire furniture. The four sculptural groups at the base of the Arc are The Triumph of 1810 (Cortot), Resistance and Peace (both by Antoine Étex) and the most renowned of them all, Departure of the Volunteers of 1792 commonly called La Marseillaise (François Rude). The face of the allegorical representation of France calling forth her people on this last was used as the belt buckle for the honorary rank of Marshal of France. Since the fall of Napoleon (1815), the sculpture representing Peace is interpreted as commemorating the Peace of 1815. In the attic above the richly sculptured frieze of soldiers are 30 shields engraved with the names of major Revolutionary and Napoleonic military victories. The inside walls of the monument list the names of 660 people, among which are 558 French generals of the First French Empire; the names of those who died in battle are underlined. Also inscribed, on the shorter sides of the four supporting columns, are the names of the major victorious battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The battles that took place in the period between the departure of Napoleon from Elba to his final defeat at Waterloo are not included. There was at the top of the Arc from 1882 to 1886, a monumental sculpture by Alexandre Falguière, "Le triomphe de la Révolution" (the Triumph of the Revolution), a chariot drawn by horses preparing "to crush Anarchy and Despotism", that remained only four years up there before falling in ruins. Inside the monument, a new permanent exhibition conceived by the artist Maurice Benayoun and the architect Christophe Girault opened in February 2007. The steel and new media installation interrogates the symbolism of the national monument, questioning the balance of its symbolic message during the last two centuries, oscillating between war and peace. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe<a>

Major academic sculptors of France are represented in the sculpture of the Arc de Triomphe: Jean-Pierre Cortot; François Rude; Antoine Étex; James Pradier and Philippe Joseph Henri Lemaire. The main sculptures are not integral friezes but are treated as independent trophies applied to the vast ashlar masonry masses, not unlike the gilt-bronze appliqués on Empire furniture. The four sculptural groups at the base of the Arc are The Triumph of 1810 (Cortot), Resistance and Peace (both by Antoine Étex) and the most renowned of them all, Departure of the Volunteers of 1792 commonly called La Marseillaise (François Rude). The face of the allegorical representation of France calling forth her people on this last was used as the belt buckle for the honorary rank of Marshal of France. Since the fall of Napoleon (1815), the sculpture representing Peace is interpreted as commemorating the Peace of 1815. In the attic above the richly sculptured frieze of soldiers are 30 shields engraved with the names of major Revolutionary and Napoleonic military victories. The inside walls of the monument list the names of 660 people, among which are 558 French generals of the First French Empire; the names of those who died in battle are underlined. Also inscribed, on the shorter sides of the four supporting columns, are the names of the major victorious battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The battles that took place in the period between the departure of Napoleon from Elba to his final defeat at Waterloo are not included. There was at the top of the Arc from 1882 to 1886, a monumental sculpture by Alexandre Falguière, "Le triomphe de la Révolution" (the Triumph of the Revolution), a chariot drawn by horses preparing "to crush Anarchy and Despotism", that remained only four years up there before falling in ruins. Inside the monument, a new permanent exhibition conceived by the artist Maurice Benayoun and the architect Christophe Girault opened in February 2007. The steel and new media installation interrogates the symbolism of the national monument, questioning the balance of its symbolic message during the last two centuries, oscillating between war and peace. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe<a>

Der Arc de Triomphe wurde von Napoleon nach der Schlacht von Austerlitz zur Verherrlichung seiner Siege 1806 in Auftrag gegeben. Am 15. August 1806 wurde der Grundstein zum Bau gelegt. Die Bauarbeiten zogen sich jedoch bis 1836 hin. Der Triumphbogen ist 49,54 m hoch, 44,82 m breit und 22 m tief. Der große Gewölbebogen misst 29,19 m in der Höhe und 14,62 m in der Breite, der kleine Bogen 18,68 m in der Höhe und 8,44 m in der Breite. Der Entwurf ist im Stil der antiken römischen Architektur gehalten. Die vier Figurengruppen an der Basis des Bogens zeigen Der Triumph von 1810, Widerstand, Frieden und La Marseillaise oder Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792 (von François Rude). Oben sind auf den Flächen rund um den Bogen Flachreliefs mit Nachbildungen von wichtigen revolutionären und napoleonischen Siegen eingelassen.Berühmt ist dieser Triumphbogen auch wegen der bedeutenden Reliefs, die er trägt. Sie wurden 1833 in Auftrag gegeben bei den Bildhauern Antoine Étex, Jean-Pierre Cortot und vor allem François Rude. Die Ostfassade zeigt das berühmteste Relief, die „Marseillaise“ (Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792) von François Rude (1784–1855), die auch „Le chant du départ“, also das Abschiedslied, genannt wird. Es handelt sich um eine Gruppe ausziehender Krieger – offensichtlich in revolutionärer oder erhoben nationaler Gesinnung, die – zumindest kann man das in dieser Szene vermuten – das neue Revolutionslied der „Marseillaise“ auf den Lippen haben, das erst am 25. April 1792 komponiert worden war. Interessant ist ein Vergleich der beiden Reliefs dieser Seite. Es handelt sich auf der anderen Seite um den „Triumph Napoleons nach dem Frieden von 1810“ (der „Triumph“ verherrlicht den Frieden von Wien) von Cortot. Das Relief von Cortot steht noch ganz in der Tradition der klassizistischen Statik, der gemessenen Heldenverehrung, des symmetrischen, wohlproportionierten Bildaufbaus – mit anderen Worten der „erhabenen Langeweile“. Auch bei den Reliefs von Antoine Etex auf der Westseite ist diese Atmosphäre deutlich zu spüren, beispielsweise beim „Frieden“. Hier hat man noch den Eindruck, dass die Themen von einer Schauspielertruppe auf einer Theaterbühne dargestellt werden, dass hier Motive aus dem Arsenal zusammengestellt worden sind. Auf den vier Außenseiten des Bodens befinden sich sechs Flachreliefs, die jeweils berühmte Schlachten zeigen. Unter den sechs Bildhauern ist auch Jean-Jacques Feuchère mit einer Darstellung des Übergangs über die Brücke von Arcole zu sehen. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29<a> The astylar design is by Jean Chalgrin (1739–1811), in the Neoclassical version of ancient Roman architecture (see, for example, the triumphal Arch of Titus). Major academic sculptors of France are represented in the sculpture of the Arc de Triomphe: Jean-Pierre Cortot; François Rude; Antoine Étex; James Pradier and Philippe Joseph Henri Lemaire. The main sculptures are not integral friezes but are treated as independent trophies applied to the vast ashlar masonry masses, not unlike the gilt-bronze appliqués on Empire furniture. The four sculptural groups at the base of the Arc are The Triumph of 1810 (Cortot), Resistance and Peace (both by Antoine Étex) and the most renowned of them all, Departure of the Volunteers of 1792 commonly called La Marseillaise (François Rude). The face of the allegorical representation of France calling forth her people on this last was used as the belt buckle for the honorary rank of Marshal of France. Since the fall of Napoleon (1815), the sculpture representing Peace is interpreted as commemorating the Peace of 1815. In the attic above the richly sculptured frieze of soldiers are 30 shields engraved with the names of major Revolutionary and Napoleonic military victories. The inside walls of the monument list the names of 660 people, among which are 558 French generals of the First French Empire; the names of those who died in battle are underlined. Also inscribed, on the shorter sides of the four supporting columns, are the names of the major victorious battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The battles that took place in the period between the departure of Napoleon from Elba to his final defeat at Waterloo are not included. There was at the top of the Arc from 1882 to 1886, a monumental sculpture by Alexandre Falguière, "Le triomphe de la Révolution" (the Triumph of the Revolution), a chariot drawn by horses preparing "to crush Anarchy and Despotism", that remained only four years up there before falling in ruins. Inside the monument, a new permanent exhibition conceived by the artist Maurice Benayoun and the architect Christophe Girault opened in February 2007. The steel and new media installation interrogates the symbolism of the national monument, questioning the balance of its symbolic message during the last two centuries, oscillating between war and peace. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe<a>

Der Arc de Triomphe wurde von Napoleon nach der Schlacht von Austerlitz zur Verherrlichung seiner Siege 1806 in Auftrag gegeben. Am 15. August 1806 wurde der Grundstein zum Bau gelegt. Die Bauarbeiten zogen sich jedoch bis 1836 hin. Der Triumphbogen ist 49,54 m hoch, 44,82 m breit und 22 m tief. Der große Gewölbebogen misst 29,19 m in der Höhe und 14,62 m in der Breite, der kleine Bogen 18,68 m in der Höhe und 8,44 m in der Breite. Der Entwurf ist im Stil der antiken römischen Architektur gehalten. Die vier Figurengruppen an der Basis des Bogens zeigen Der Triumph von 1810, Widerstand, Frieden und La Marseillaise oder Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792 (von François Rude). Oben sind auf den Flächen rund um den Bogen Flachreliefs mit Nachbildungen von wichtigen revolutionären und napoleonischen Siegen eingelassen.Berühmt ist dieser Triumphbogen auch wegen der bedeutenden Reliefs, die er trägt. Sie wurden 1833 in Auftrag gegeben bei den Bildhauern Antoine Étex, Jean-Pierre Cortot und vor allem François Rude. Die Ostfassade zeigt das berühmteste Relief, die „Marseillaise“ (Auszug der Freiwilligen von 1792) von François Rude (1784–1855), die auch „Le chant du départ“, also das Abschiedslied, genannt wird. Es handelt sich um eine Gruppe ausziehender Krieger – offensichtlich in revolutionärer oder erhoben nationaler Gesinnung, die – zumindest kann man das in dieser Szene vermuten – das neue Revolutionslied der „Marseillaise“ auf den Lippen haben, das erst am 25. April 1792 komponiert worden war. Interessant ist ein Vergleich der beiden Reliefs dieser Seite. Es handelt sich auf der anderen Seite um den „Triumph Napoleons nach dem Frieden von 1810“ (der „Triumph“ verherrlicht den Frieden von Wien) von Cortot. Das Relief von Cortot steht noch ganz in der Tradition der klassizistischen Statik, der gemessenen Heldenverehrung, des symmetrischen, wohlproportionierten Bildaufbaus – mit anderen Worten der „erhabenen Langeweile“. Auch bei den Reliefs von Antoine Etex auf der Westseite ist diese Atmosphäre deutlich zu spüren, beispielsweise beim „Frieden“. Hier hat man noch den Eindruck, dass die Themen von einer Schauspielertruppe auf einer Theaterbühne dargestellt werden, dass hier Motive aus dem Arsenal zusammengestellt worden sind. Auf den vier Außenseiten des Bodens befinden sich sechs Flachreliefs, die jeweils berühmte Schlachten zeigen. Unter den sechs Bildhauern ist auch Jean-Jacques Feuchère mit einer Darstellung des Übergangs über die Brücke von Arcole zu sehen. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiTriumphbogen_%28Paris%29<a> The astylar design is by Jean Chalgrin (1739–1811), in the Neoclassical version of ancient Roman architecture (see, for example, the triumphal Arch of Titus). Major academic sculptors of France are represented in the sculpture of the Arc de Triomphe: Jean-Pierre Cortot; François Rude; Antoine Étex; James Pradier and Philippe Joseph Henri Lemaire. The main sculptures are not integral friezes but are treated as independent trophies applied to the vast ashlar masonry masses, not unlike the gilt-bronze appliqués on Empire furniture. The four sculptural groups at the base of the Arc are The Triumph of 1810 (Cortot), Resistance and Peace (both by Antoine Étex) and the most renowned of them all, Departure of the Volunteers of 1792 commonly called La Marseillaise (François Rude). The face of the allegorical representation of France calling forth her people on this last was used as the belt buckle for the honorary rank of Marshal of France. Since the fall of Napoleon (1815), the sculpture representing Peace is interpreted as commemorating the Peace of 1815. In the attic above the richly sculptured frieze of soldiers are 30 shields engraved with the names of major Revolutionary and Napoleonic military victories. The inside walls of the monument list the names of 660 people, among which are 558 French generals of the First French Empire; the names of those who died in battle are underlined. Also inscribed, on the shorter sides of the four supporting columns, are the names of the major victorious battles of the Napoleonic Wars. The battles that took place in the period between the departure of Napoleon from Elba to his final defeat at Waterloo are not included. There was at the top of the Arc from 1882 to 1886, a monumental sculpture by Alexandre Falguière, "Le triomphe de la Révolution" (the Triumph of the Revolution), a chariot drawn by horses preparing "to crush Anarchy and Despotism", that remained only four years up there before falling in ruins. Inside the monument, a new permanent exhibition conceived by the artist Maurice Benayoun and the architect Christophe Girault opened in February 2007. The steel and new media installation interrogates the symbolism of the national monument, questioning the balance of its symbolic message during the last two centuries, oscillating between war and peace. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe<a>

La Marsellaise (Depature of the Volunteers) adorns the lower section of the northeast pillar of the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1427731797">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a>, facing <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1428522133">Avenue de Champs-Élysées<a>. The sculptured high relief, executed by François Rude, represents the Genius of Liberty in the guise of a winged female emitting a cry of warning in the face of enemy invasion. She incites the people to battle by brandishing a sword. Beneath her, a bearded, breast-plated warrior leads along a naked youth by the shoulders, while waving his helmet to signal departure and unification. He seems indifferent to the advice apparently offered to him by a bearded old man in the background. To the right, carrying a shield and draped in a coat, another warrior readies himself to follow his companions. To the left, a stopping soldier braces himself, while behind, a man wearing a helmet sounds the trumpet. A last soldier reins in a whinnying horse by his bridle. Rude illustrates a basic event in Revolutionary history: the Conscription of 1792 which involved the levying of 200,000 men en masse under orders of the Legislative Assembly in order to organize the defense of France against foreign armies allied against the Revolutionaries. This massive conscription had secured the first victory of Revolution against a foreign power at the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1444587485">Battle of Valmy against Prussia<a> on September 20, 1792. Shortly thereafter, the Revolutionary armies won a battle against Austria at Jemmapes on November 6, 1792. Although Rude was celebrating the Conscription in memorial with this work, he did so in an allegorical manner. By employing neither costumes of the epoch nor contemporary Revolutionary arms, he presented a universal struggle of a people in defense of their territory. The face of the allegorical representation of France calling forth her people on this last was used as the belt buckle for the seven-star rank of Marshal of France. Famously it is said that her sword broke off on the day that the Battle of Verdun began in 1916. The relief was immediately hidden by tarpaulins to conceal the accident and avoid any ominous interpretations. The Arc de Triomphe stands in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle, also known as the Place de l'Étoile (Star Square). Designed by Jean Chalgrin between 1806 and 1836, the 51 meter high, 45-meter wide monument is the second largest triumphal arch in existence. It honors those who fought for France, particularly during the Napoleonic Wars.

La prise d'Alexandrie le 3 juillet 1798 (The Conquest of Alexandia) adorns the upper section of the southwest pillar of the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1427731797">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a>, above the relief, <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1428450949"><i>La Paix<a><i>, facing Avenue de la Grand-Armeé. The sculptured relief, executed by John Chaponnière, depicts General Jean Baptiste Kléber and his soldiers, reached the summits of the Alexandrian ramparts on July 3, 1798 as part of the Egyptian Campaign. Having suffered a Wounded to the head, Kléber is portrayed holding his right hand to his forehead and pointing to the enemy with the sword in his left. A French soldier pierces his bayonnet into the chest of a Turk who injured Kléber , while a nude Egyptian prepares to stab him. Behind Kléber, a solider rips his cartouche, as a second one mounts the last step which gives out onto the ramparts. To the left, one last soldier appeals to his companions. The Arc de Triomphe stands in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle, also known as the Place de l'Étoile (Star Square). It honors those who fought for France, particularly during the Napoleonic Wars.

Le prototype du télescope de réalité augmentée du CITU mis en service sur le toit de l'Arc de Triomphe dans le cadre de Futur en Seine, avec le soutien du Centre des Monuments Nationaux. <a href"http:www.citu.infoprojet_34_1" rel"nofollow">www.citu.infoprojet_34_1<a> Le dispositif présenté en est encore au stade du laboratoire. Des mises au point et des améliorations seront faites dans les mois qui viennent. La mise à disposition du public de ce télescope numérique, dont le concept est très innovant, fera certainement l'objet d'une grande curiosité, il faudra néanmoins que le service de localisation fourni et que les informations apportées sur les monuments, compensent dans l'esprit des touristes la moins bonne qualité des images numériques en comparaison de celle des images optiques. <a href"http:www.futur-en-seine.orgfr" rel"nofollow">www.futur-en-seine.orgfr<a>

La Résistance (The Resistance), also referred to as La Résistance de 1814 (The Resistance of 1814), adorns the lower section of the southwest pillar of the <a href"http:www.flickr.comphotoswallyg1427731797">Arc de Triomphe de l'Étoile<a>, facing Avenue de la Grand-Armeé. The sculptured high relief, executed by Antoine Etex, symbolizes the Nation's resistance in 1814 when faced with the invasion of foreign forces united against Napoléon. The Russians and Austrians had invaded French territory and occupied Paris. With left fist clenched and rght hand armed with a double edged sword, a standing nude warrior readies himself to leave in defense in of his native land. To his right, his aged father holds him back by the leg. To his left, holding thei child in aoutstretched arms, his wife, too, attempts to retain him. Behind him, a bearded horseman falls from his saddle as though struck down in full action, symbolizing a patriots's sacrifice for his country. The Spirit of the Future, with Wings deployed, forehead bearing a flame, and sword in hand, dictates to the soldier his duty to resist The Arc de Triomphe stands in the centre of the Place Charles de Gaulle, also known as the Place de l'Étoile (Star Square). Designed by Jean Chalgrin between 1806 and 1836, the 51 meter high, 45-meter wide monument is the second largest triumphal arch in existence. It honors those who fought for France, particularly during the Napoleonic Wars.

Dispositif multimédia interactif pour voir sur écran les frises et sculptures de l'Arc de Triomphe. Le point lumineux sur la maquette de l'Arc indique la position des images vues sur l'écran. Le Centre des Monuments Nationaux a confié à la société Hyptique la réalisation du parcours audiovisuel interactif défini par Benayoun et Girault pour rénouveler les salles permanentes de l'Arc de triomphe de Paris. Plusieurs dispositifs ont été mis en œuvre dont ce dispositif qui propose l'orientation interactive d'une maquette de l'Arc, dans le but d'éclairer un détail des sculptures qui couvrent le monument et d'en afficher le détail. <a href"http:arc-de-triomphe.monuments-nationaux.frfr">arc-de-triomphe.monuments-nationaux.frfr<a>

Found in the Place du Carrousel, on the site of the former Tuileries Palace, at the west of the Louvre. The arch was built between 1806-08, designed by Charles Percier (1764-1838) and Pierre François Léonard Fontaine (1762-1853). The design was to mark the military victory of Napoleon Bonaparte (Emperor Napoleon I), and act as the gateway to the imperial residence in the Tuileries Palace (which was later destroyed in 1871 during the Paris Commune). The arch was originally topped with a quadriga (chariot led by 4 horses) from Saint Mark's Cathedral in Venice (captured in 1798 by Napoleon), but these were returned in 1815 following Waterloo. A replacement quadriga designed by Baron François Joseph Bosio (1769-1845), this one showed Peace led by gilded Victories, representing the restoration of the Bourbons. Taken in the Palais du Louvre (Louvre Palace). The palais occupies the site of the original Louvre fortress (the name Louvre comes from "leower" a Frankish word meaning a fortified palace), dating from the c12th until its destruction in 1546 by Francis I. Francis built a new royal palace that consecutive monarchs added to, the last work by a Bourbon monarch was initiated in 1659, when Louis XIV ordered the creation of the eastern wing (1665–80), designed by Claude Perrault (1613-88). In 1678 the royal palace moved to Versailles, and the Louvre was turned into an art gallery. Napoleons I and III added to the complex; the former had the Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel built between the two western wings, and the latter added a new wing designed by architects Louis Visconti (1791-1853) and Hector Lefuel (1782-1850)

<b>Surmoulage de la tête de l'allégorie féminine de la Patrie, dite la Renommée<b> du relief "Le Départ des volontaires de 1792 appelé La Marseillaise" situé sur l'Arc de Triomphe à Paris. Ce groupe a été sculpté par François Rude (1784-1855) entre 1833 et 1836 Le moulage de la Renommée (qui est une figure de Victoire antique) et de l'éphèbe nu placé en avant du groupe a été effectué en 1896 par crainte des dégradations ou de la destruction de l'original. Le moulage des autres éléments n'a été fait qu'en 1938, ainsi qu'un surmoulage de la tête présentée actuellement dans le musée. Exposition-dossier "Le cri et le geste" sur les maquettes et moulages de l'Arc de Triomphe Cité de l'architecture et du patrimoine <a href"http:www.citechaillot.frfrexpositionsexpositions_temporaires24771-le_cri_et_le_geste.html" rel"nofollow">www.citechaillot.frfrexpositionsexpositions_temporaire...<a> <i>Cette petite exposition appelée "le cri et le geste", en référence à l'expressivité de la figure allégorique de la Marseillaise, le plus célèbre bas-relief de l'Arc de Triomphe, évoque au sein même de la galerie des moulages de la Cité de l'architecture et du patrimoine, l'histoire mouvementée de la construction de ce monument emblématique de la République française. Deux maquettes des premiers projets d'arc de triomphe sont présentées ainsi que des parties des moulages du bas-relief : la tête de la Renommée et sa main tendue en signe de victoire. On apprend dans cette exposition-dossier que le moulage de l'éphèbe, placé en 1896 sous celui de la Renommée, sur le mur du fond du musée des monuments français, avait fait scandale en raison d'une nudité un peu trop visible. Des enseignantes en visite guidée avec des jeunes filles s'en étaient émues auprès de la direction du musée de l'époque. La proximité avec ces moulages permet au visiteur de se rendre compte de la taille des sculptures mais aussi de leur tension exceptionnelle, qui fait écho aux paroles de l'hymne national français. <i>

Der Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel befindet sich zwischen Tuilerien und Place du Carrousel auf der sogenannten Axe historique, die sich vom Louvre aus geradlinig westnordwestwärts durch Paris und zwei Nachbarstädte erstreckt. Am 27. Februar 1806 beauftragte Napoleon I. per Dekret die Architekten Charles Percier und Pierre-François-Léonard Fontaine mit der Realisierung und den Generaldirektor der Museen, Vivant Denon, mit der Planung des Skulpturendekors. Für die Entwürfe der Reliefs und Statuen wählte Denon Charles Meynier. Ausgeführt wurden die Reliefs und Statuen von verschiedenen Bildhauern, u. a. Clodion. Die Szenen beziehen sich auf die siegreiche Kampagne der französischen Armee von 1805 (Schlacht bei Austerlitz) und die Kapitulation von Ulm im Jahre 1807. <a href"http:de.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe_du_Carrousel" rel"nofollow">de.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe_du_Carrousel<a> The Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel is a triumphal arch in Paris, located in the Place du Carrousel on the site of the former Tuileries Palace. It was built between 1806 and 1808 to commemorate Napoleon's military victories of the previous year. The monument is 63 feet (19 m) high, 75 feet (23 m) wide, and 24 feet (7.3 m) deep. The 21 feet (6.4 m) high central arch is flanked by two smaller ones, 14 feet (4.3 m) high, and 9 feet (2.7 m) wide. Around its exterior are eight Corinthian columns of marble, topped by eight soldiers of the Empire. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe_du_Carrousel" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiArc_de_Triomphe_du_Carrousel<a>
